animalOfTheDay.name: walrus
facts: They are social animals and live in large herds.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.
They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.

calendar.name: umbrellabird
facts: Umbrellabirds get their name from the distinctive umbrella-like crest on the male's head.
They have one of the deepest voices in the bird world, producing loud, booming calls.
They are found only in the rainforests of Central and South America.
Males gather in groups called leks to perform courtship displays for females.

calendar.name: vampire bat
facts: Vampires run on ground using folded wings as front legs.
Bat saliva contains draculin – an anticoagulant studied for stroke treatment.
They use infrared sensors on noses to detect blood vessels.
Vampire bats share regurgitated blood with starving colony members – reciprocal altruism.

calendar.name: vicuna
facts: Vicuñas produce the finest wool – fibers measure 12 micrometers (human hair: 75).
They have lower incisor teeth that grow continuously like rodents.
Inca royalty wore vicuña robes; illegal poaching still threatens populations.
Vicuñas spit foul-smelling cud at competitors during disputes.

calendar.name: viper
facts: Vipers have heat-sensing pits detecting temperature changes as small as 0.003°C.
Their hinged fangs fold against the roof of mouth when not striking.
Horned vipers in deserts move via sidewinding to avoid hot sand.
Gaboon vipers have longest fangs (2 inches) and highest venom yield.

calendar.name: vulture
facts: Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They have an excellent sense of smell.

calendar.name: wallaby
facts: They practice embryonic diapause; pausing development until environmental conditions improve.
Rock wallabies scale cliffs using textured soles and tail balancing.
Wallabies cool by licking forearms; saliva evaporation lowers blood temperature.
Wallabies hop efficiently – energy use doesn't increase with speed.

calendar.name: walrus
facts: They are found in Arctic waters.
Walruses are large marine mammals known for their prominent tusks.
They are social animals and live in large herds.
Walruses use their tusks to haul themselves onto ice and to forage for food.

randomAnimals.name: cockatiel
facts: They're originally from Australia and are part of the cockatoo family.
Male cockatiels are typically better singers than females.
Their head crests indicate their emotional state - up when excited, flat when calm.
Cockatiels can learn to whistle tunes and mimic household sounds.

randomAnimals.name: sandpiper
facts: Sandpipers have specialized bills that can sense vibrations of prey underground.
Sandpipers are shorebirds with long bills for probing sand and mud for food.
Some species undertake incredible migrations, flying nonstop for days over open ocean.
They perform elaborate aerial displays during courtship.

randomAnimals.name: praying mantis
facts: Females sometimes eat males during mating, though this is less common than believed.
Some mantis species mimic flowers to ambush pollinators.
Praying mantises can rotate their heads 180 degrees to scan for prey.
They have excellent vision, with two large compound eyes and three simple eyes.
